title: Team goes 0/13 Before I Get Level 6, How Can I Win?
body: Mods keep removing my posts, so I'll ask this. In a "team-based" game, how can you come back from a 0-13 score difference after 10 mins in game?

replies.body:
You're not going to win every game.

The key to climbing is to not get so tilted from the games you will no doubt lose, that you end up losing games that could have ended up being winnable.

I find my biggest problem when on a losing streak is I repeatedly get team after team where my allies feed early, and I get depressed that I'm bound to lose another game and start losing myself too (going for too big of plays to make up for my allies losing). Some of those end up being close losses, and if I had played  better could have been wins.

Some games are just guaranteed losses though. You can't carry 4 guys that don't want to win.

Having a strategy to win and sharing that strategy with the team is a slippery slope.

I like your name btw, pretty much defines my role in every game.

And as for how you get matched up with strategically inept people, my theory has been this:

There are 2 ways to get into a rank:

1. Have good macro.

2. Have good mechanics.

You can climb as high as Diamond 1 with great macro and bad mechanics and vice versa, maybe even further than that.

So usually your team will end up having either people with one of the two or a balanced mix of both. And when a mechanics player gets behind their impact on the overall game goes way down since they rely mostly on outplaying opponents mechanically as opposed to with macro. If their stats are just too low to accomplish mechanical outplays, their overall impact suffers tremendously.

I personally view myself as having absolutely terrible mechanics but great macro (I couldn't play something like Riven to save my life).

That's why I pick champions that are relatively low on mechanical skill but are able to create map impact, and probably why the opposite players pick stuff like Kat or Zed and gun for kills.

You're going to have a lot of games where your team sucks early on.

A lot of those games, your team has decent players that are capable of making a comeback if no one tilts out and just started feeding though. Especially if you personally are even or slightly ahead and can help stall.

Some of those games, your teammates are just idiots that can't do anything right. It doesn't matter how much you try to stay in it if your 0/5 ADC insists on venturing out alone against 2 fed assassins. 

The key to climbing is to not contribute to the problem in any games, so that when you're in the former scenario you actually turn some of those games around and win them (because you know full well you're not winning 100% of games where you start out with a lead).

If you can ward smart enough that they don't pop your vision you can actually catch out the enemy team a lot.   

Defending teams usually can rotate much quicker than attacking teams due to taking short cuts through the base.  With this knowledge all you need to do is spot 1 or 2 people on the enemy team basing or out of position and ping/collapse on the remaining enemy players.  

The enemy will get there slower and so it will be a numbers advantage (should cover the gold difference) in your favor for quite a while.
As long as the combined gold of your 5 players is greater than the gold of the 4/3 players you are fighting, you should easily win.

When you are forced to cs under tower, does this affect your ability to carry games? How do you find/gain leads while in this position?

Generally, I try to keep lanes pushed as Sivir, because it's easy and fast to do so. I only get shoved under tower when I can't clear waves fast enough (first levels) or when I'm so behind and the enemy can easily engage me.

If that's the case, then it's hard to come back from these games, honestly. It's not in your hands anymore, it's up to the enemy to make mistakes and capitalize on them, and this probably needs to happen a lot. What I do in these situations is try to waveclear and rotate around and map to keep towers safe and keep my CS up, pick up jungle camps when I can and try to keep vision on objectives, mostly Baron. As long as I can stall the game and keep csing, I have a chance. Sometimes, I even starve my team from csing themselves because I believe in myself to carry as Sivir late.

So yeah, when you are forced to stay under tower, try to stall. Just hard waveclear, even if it means you lose some cs. Big leads are obtained when a team can take towers, then rotate to take other towers, not by missing like 5-10 cs to protect a tower. It's all about momentum and how hard you can snowball. Denying snowball from the enemy is very important when playing from behind. 

Sometimes, when they realize they can't really push against me, they leave lane and try to take another tower instead. For example, when they already take my first bot tower and realize it's risky to take my second one, they leave and rotate top to take that one. That's where I can farm up safely and because of my pushing power, I can fast push to the enemy tower. Eventually I either trade towers top for bot (trading  equally when behind is really good), or I force them to abandon their top siege and come bot to defend. It's even more evident when I have also taken the bot tower, then then there's a long lane to push, I fast push it to their second tower and chip it down for like 500HP then back off. I force the enemy to come and clear that wave, and push it all the way to my tower, during which time I rotate to some other lane to do the exact same thing, or pick up jungle camps. Since my push is faster than pretty much anyone, I can rotate, shove waves, then return to bot to do the exact same thing. As long as I know where my enemies are, I can do that indefinitely till I chip down enough towers and farm up and outpace the enemy team.

If anything, it all comes down to how experienced you are in the champion you play and what you are up against. If you go against Brand - Caitlyn, then that's a nightmare lane and you can't even cs under tower as easily. In such a situation, abandoning the tower and free farming under second tower and using the pushing technique I stated above is really good. Sure, you might lose pressure on the map, your mid laner is probably not gonna have a good time, but when you play against a strong early game team, losing the minimum is of unmatched importance.

EDIT: Don't play Sivir in any elo below Diamond 3. It's really hard to win games with her because people don't understand how to work with Sivir. They try to force fights early when Sivir isn't as strong as other ADCs, lose them and fall behind and then act all surprised. Sivir is the champion that wants to wait 25 minutes and then do anything. She's all about game control, push waves, slowly chip down towers etc. Not the most fancy of gameplay, but damn effective if played correctly.
